title: 110_hr2341
content: The Act is titled the "Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge Act" and addresses nonpublic information relating to Congress. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit buying or selling securities based on nonpublic information related to pending legislative actions involving an issuer, if obtained from or by a Member or employee of Congress. This is part of the "Stop Trading on Congressional Knowledge Act." The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to prohibit trading securities based on material nonpublic information obtained from federal employment, with a focus on information related to issuers. The term 'material nonpublic information' refers to information obtained by a federal employee that has not been made available to the general public, including information exempt from disclosure or designated as confidential. This applies to commodities transactions under the Commodities Exchange Act. The Commodities Exchange Act is amended to prohibit buying or selling commodities based on material nonpublic information related to pending legislative actions obtained from Congress members or employees. The Commodities Exchange Act prohibits buying or selling commodities based on material nonpublic information derived from Federal employment within 270 days of enactment. The term 'material nonpublic information' refers to information gained by a federal agency employee through their job that has not been made public, including information exempt from disclosure laws, designated as confidential, or not disseminated to the public. SEC. 3. AMENDMENT TO THE RULES OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES REGARDING SECURITIES TRADING BASED ON NONPUBLIC INFORMATION. Rule XXIII of the House of Representatives' Code of Official Conduct is amended to prohibit members and employees from disclosing nonpublic information related to legislative actions on publicly-traded companies for securities trading purposes. The House of Representatives' Code of Official Conduct is amended to prohibit members and employees from disclosing nonpublic information related to legislative actions on commodities for trading purposes. SEC. 4. TIMELY REPORTING OF SECURITIES TRANSACTIONS. Amendment to the Ethics in Government Act of 1978 requires Members of Congress and legislative branch employees to report transactions involving at least $1000 in securities within 90 days. Effective for transactions occurring 90 days after enactment. SEC. 5. REGISTRATION OF POLITICAL INTELLIGENCE FIRMS.
